clean_content:
Definition / general

* Locally invasive, nonmetastasizing, highly differentiated, exophytic variant of squamous cell carcinoma

Essential features

* 2 - 12% of all oral carcinomas ([Int J Oncol 2016;49:59](27121637))* M > F; sixth to seventh decades of life* May occur at any oral or pharyngeal site, although the oral cavity (tongue, buccal mucosa, alveolar mucosa) is the most common site* Characterized by slow growing, verrucoid / cauliflower-like exophytic growth* Elongated and bulbous rete ridges exhibiting a pushing margin below the level of intact, uninvolved surface epithelium; church spire peaks of keratin, keratin clefting and bland cytology

Terminology

* Use of historic term Ackerman tumor not recommended by 5th edition of the World Health Organization

ICD coding

* ICD-10: [C00 - C14](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/C00-D49/C00-C14) - malignant neoplasm of lip, oral cavity and pharynx

Epidemiology

* 2 - 12% of all oral carcinomas ([Int J Oncol 2016;49:59](27121637))* M > F* Sixth to seventh decades of life; mean age at diagnosis: 69.5 years (1973 - 2012) ([Laryngoscope 2018;128:393](28850720))

Sites

* Oral tongue, alveolar ridge and buccal mucosa are the most common sites ([Laryngoscope 2018;128:393](28850720), [Int J Oncol 2016;49:59](27121637))

Pathophysiology

* Multistep process involving genetic alterations / predisposition and environmental influences ([Int J Oncol 2016;49:59](27121637))* Several biomarkers have been studied / identified; however, *DAMTS12, COL4A1, COL4A2, INHBA, MMP1, SEROINE1, TGFBI* and *HLF* are all genes that are expressed differently in oral verrucous carcinoma when compared to traditional oral squamous cell carcinoma, suggesting future therapeutic potential ([Int J Clin Exp Med 2014;7:1845](25126189), [Int J Oncol 2016;49:59](27121637))

Etiology

* Proliferative verrucous leukoplakia (PVL) is a known risk factor ([Cancers (Basel) 2021;13:4085](34439238))
  + 29.5% prevalence of developing verrucous carcinoma in patients with proliferative verrucous leukoplakia ([Cancers (Basel) 2021;13:4085](34439238))* Associations (synergistic or independent) with tobacco use, areca nut chewing, chronic inflammation, alcohol consumption, antioxidant deficient diet and oral microbiota ([Int J Oncol 2016;49:59](27121637))* Controversial association with HPV in older literature; no conclusive association has been proven ([Int J Oncol 2016;49:59](27121637), [Arch Otolaryngol Head Neck Surg 1993;119:1299](17431983), [Pathobiology 2008;75:257](18580072), [Tumour Biol 2011;32:409](21136231), [Radiat Res 1970;41:375](4908602))
      + No transcriptionally active high risk HPV has been identified ([Hum Pathol 2013;44:2385](24071016))

Clinical features

* Exophytic, papillary or verrucoid mass* Slow growth* Locoregional metastasis and or bone involvement suggests transformation (or component) of conventional invasive squamous cell carcinoma ([Int J Oncol 2016;49:59](27121637))

Diagnosis

* Along with supportive histopathology, diagnosis may incorporate one or more elements such as patient history, symptoms, clinical examination and imaging

Prognostic factors

* Nodal disease is found in 1.6% of cases and likely can be attributed to transformation into traditional invasive squamous cell carcinoma ([Laryngoscope 2018;128:393](28850720))* 2, 5 and 10 year survival rates are 83%, 64% and 42%, respectively ([Laryngoscope 2018;128:393](28850720))* Recurrence rate is high if incompletely excised

Case reports

* 14 year old boy with xeroderma pigmentosum presented with verrucous carcinoma on the tip of the tongue ([Cureus 2022;14:e31706](36561591))* 30 year old gutka chewer and 60 year old patient with an areca nut and tobacco chewing habit both presented with white verrucoid lesions of the oral cavity ([Contemp Clin Dent 2016;7:391](27630507))* 56 year old man with verrucous carcinoma treated successfully with topical 5-aminolevulinic acid mediated photodynamic therapy ([J Oral Pathol Med 2005;34:253](15752262))* 67 year old woman presented with a slowly growing, white verrucoid lesion on the maxillary alveolar ridge ([Case Rep Oncol Med 2012;2012:190272](22720181))

Treatment

* Surgical removal with adequate margins is preferred treatment ([Contemp Clin Dent 2012;3:60](22557899), [Int J Oncol 2016;49:59](27121637))* Chemotherapy and radiation have questionable effectiveness due to poor response and anaplastic transformation ([Int J Oncol 2016;49:59](27121637), [Laryngoscope 2017;127:1334](28150306))

Clinical images

Contributed by Molly Housley Smith, D.M.D., Thamer Musbah, M.D., Thomas C. Ocheltree, M.D. and Steven Anderson, M.D.  

[![Verrucous carcinoma within PVL](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith01.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith01.jpg)

Verrucous carcinoma within PVL

[![Exophytic white mass](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousMusbah01.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousMusbah01.jpg)

Exophytic white mass

[![Verrucoid mass of alveolus](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousOcheltree01.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousOcheltree01.jpg)

Verrucoid mass of alveolus

[![Exophytic verrucoid labial mass](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousAnderson01.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousAnderson01.jpg)

Exophytic verrucoid labial mass

Gross description

* White / tan* Exophytic, papillary, fungating, cauliflower-like growth ([J Maxillofac Oral Surg 2011;10:148](22654367))* May bluntly invade adjacent soft tissue

Gross images

Contributed by Molly Housley Smith, D.M.D.  

[![Exophytic and downward growth](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith02.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith02.jpg)

Exophytic and downward growth

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Poor interobserver agreement among pathologists ([Head Neck Pathol 2020;14:156](30972634))
  + Lack of consistency with terminology for verrucoid lesions creates confusion for clinicians ([Head Neck Pathol 2020;14:156](30972634))* Well differentiated / cytologically bland, hyperplastic squamous epithelium* Broad, bulbous, plunging rete ridges that demonstrate pushing encroachment on muscle or other deep submucosal structures, below the level of intact normal epithelium ([Head Neck Pathol 2021;15:572](33415517))* Church spire-like or papillary hyperkeratosis with deep keratin clefting* Intact basement membrane ([Contemp Clin Dent 2016;7:391](27630507))* Minimal cytologic atypia* Inward cupping of the rete pegs is not apparent

Microscopic (histologic) images

Contributed by Molly Housley Smith, D.M.D.  

[![Hyperplastic, bulbous rete ridges](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith03.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith03.jpg)

Hyperplastic, bulbous rete ridges

[![Church spire keratin peaks](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith04.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith04.jpg)

Church spire keratin peaks

[![Broad, plunging rete ridges](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith03b.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith03b.jpg)

Broad, plunging rete ridges

[![Keratin plugging](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith05.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith05.jpg)

Keratin plugging

[![Cytologically bland ](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith05b.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith05b.jpg)
â€ƒ
[![Cytologically bland](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith06.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith06.jpg)

Cytologically bland

Videos

Verrucous carcinoma

Cutaneous verrucous carcinoma

Sample pathology report

* Right buccal mucosa, biopsy:
  + Verrucous carcinoma (see comment)+ Comment: Microscopic examination reveals atypical superficial stratified squamous epithelium overlying fibrous connective tissue. The epithelium exhibits a significantly thickened layer of orthokeratin that forms prominent church spire-like peaks. The rete ridges are bulbous and elongated, forming a broad, pushing margin that abuts skeletal muscle. Prominent keratin clefting / plugging is apparent. The underlying connective tissue contains a dense mixed inflammatory cell infiltrate immediately subjacent to the epithelial proliferation.

Differential diagnosis

* [Oral squamous papilloma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavitysquamouspapilloma.html):


  [![Papilloma clinical appearance](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousKentucky01.png)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousKentucky01.png)

  [![Papilloma histology](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith07.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith07.jpg)

  + May be difficult to differentiate from verrucous carcinoma on small, incisional or fragmented biopsies
    - Caution is advised when making a diagnosis of papilloma on incisional or fragmented biopsies or when the lesion is not well circumscribed or symmetrical+ Limited growth potential, often small+ Papillary, finger-like projections with fibrovascular connective tissue cores+ Often pedunculated but may be sessile+ Well defined margins+ Lacks endophytic growth pattern+ Lacks prominent hypergranulosis+ Variable keratinization ([Head Neck Pathol 2019;13:80](30693456))  
  * **Condyloma acuminatum**:


    [![Condyloma clinical appearance](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousBelani01.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousBelani01.jpg)

    [![Condyloma histology](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith08.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith08.jpg)

    + Labial mucosa, soft palate, lingual frenum+ Often demonstrates a fleshy, broad based clinical appearance but should demonstrate circumscription and symmetry+ Bulbous rete pegs and blunted papillary projections+ Exophytic; lacks broad, pushing, endophytic growth pattern  
    * [Pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavitypseudoephyperplasia.html):


      [![Pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith09a.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith09a.jpg)

      [![Pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith09b.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith09b.jpg)

      - Associated with chronic candidiasis and granular cell tumor- Extreme caution is recommended in diagnosing pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia, as secondary candidal colonization may be seen on atypical epithelial processes (e.g., verrucous carcinoma)
          * Excision or rebiopsy of lesional tissue remaining after antifungal therapy may be recommended- Lacks prominent exophytic growth pattern and endophytic pushing margin into bone or skeletal muscle  
      * [Verruciform xanthoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavityverruciformxanthoma.html):


        [![Verruciform xanthoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith10a.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith10a.jpg)

        [![Verruciform xanthoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith10b.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith10b.jpg)

        + May demonstrate similar clinical characteristics, although may have yellow hue+ Demonstrates foamy xanthoma cells within papillary projections  
        * [Proliferative verrucous leukoplakia](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavityverrucoushyperplasia.html) / [verrucous leukoplakia](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavityleukoplakia.html):


          [![Proliferative verrucous leukoplakia](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith11.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith11.jpg)

          + Characterized by multifocal white plaques with well defined margins+ High transformation rate into verrucous carcinoma or squamous cell carcinoma+ Very similar histology to the bulky hyperkeratotic epithelial proliferation category of proliferative verrucous leukoplakia proposed by Thompson et al. in 2021 ([Head Neck Pathol 2021;15:572](33415517))
                - Verruciform, church spire-like keratin peaks, prominent endophytic growth with bulbous, hyperplastic rete ridges and keratin plugging- Lacks the pushing architectural pattern  
          * [Squamous cell carcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavityscc.html):


            [![Carcinoma cuniculatum](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith12.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith12.jpg)

            Carcinoma cuniculatum

            [![Papillary squamous cell carcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith13.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityverrucousSmith13.jpg)

            Papillary squamous cell carcinoma

            - Squamous cell carcinoma (SCCa) may arise within verrucous carcinoma- Overt evidence of connective tissue invasion lacking intact basement membrane; SCCa shows infiltrative nests of epithelium and may invade into or around nerves, blood vessels or salivary glands- SCCa may also infiltrate into skeletal muscle bundles, as opposed to verrucous carcinoma, which only pushes into the skeletal muscle- Carcinoma cuniculatum and papillary squamous cell carcinoma in particular may be confused with verrucous carcinoma
                    * Carcinoma cuniculatum demonstrates deep burrowing of the epithelium with keratin filled crypts ([J Clin Diagn Res 2017;11:ZD37](28274074))* Papillary SCCa likely is confusing based on its name* Papillary SCCa demonstrates a papillary or filiform architecture (like verrucous carcinoma) but lacks prominent surface keratinization and cytologically exhibits malignant epithelium

Additional references

* [Wenig: Atlas of Head and Neck Pathology, 3rd Edition, 2015](https://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/1455733822/pathologyoutl-20),
  [Neville: Oral and Maxillofacial Pathology, 4th Edition, 2015](https://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/1455770523/pathologyoutl-20)
